Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards Inter-Sentential Models for Detecting Focus of Negation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding language is at the core of intelligent systems, and a required component of several end-user applications such as machine translation, question answering and text summarization. Most computational approaches to extract meaning from text build a semantic representation capturing some of the meaning intuitively understood by humans when reading text. For example, semantic role labelers extract who did what to whom, how, when and where from plain text, and semantic parsers transform text into logic forms. This exploratory EAGER project defines new algorithms for extracting positive interpretations from negated statements by detecting the focus of negation, that is, pinpointing the usually few text chunks within a negation that are intended to be negated.

Negation is an intricate linguistic phenomenon present in all human languages. From a theoretical point of view, it is well known that negation often carries positive meanings ranging from implicatures to entailments. Despite this observation, current computational approaches to understand the effects of negation are limited to scope detection and disregard the numerous positive interpretations immediately understood by humans when reading text with negated elements. This project builds inter-sentential models to detect the foci of negation, a key component to extract positive interpretations from negations. Exploiting the context surrounding a negation is key to improving foci detection, as existing intra-sentential models fail to take into account key related events that signal the correct foci out of the many potential foci for a given negation. Being able to extract positive interpretations from negation will benefit the overall extraction of meaning from text, since once positive interpretations associated with negative expressions have been identified, they can be integrated with the interpretations obtained for the text as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Negation is an intricate phenomenon that reverses the polarity of a chunk of text. It is often the case that the negated chunk, generally referred to as the focus of the negation, is a small portion of a sentence. Despite tremendous improvements in natural language understanding, intelligent systems currently struggle to pinpoint the focus of negation. This challenge hinders development of intelligent systems that can interact with humans using natural language, as negation appears in between 10 to 20 percent of sentences depending on the domain and genre.

This project made two main contribution towards solving this challenging problem: 

- First, we studied the role of discourse structure. Discourse structure captures how text from different sentences are connected to form a coherent structure. This inter-sentential information is important to pinpoint the focus, and we showed that an off-the-shelf discourse parser brings improvements with sentences containing 20 or more tokens.

- Second, we created a resource to investigate the positive interpretations humans understand after reading sentences containing negation within a discourse. Beyond identifying the focus of negation, this resource substitutes the focus of negation with plausible positive interpretations. For example, given 'I will never forget the morning when I started my first job', it contains the following positive interpretation: 'I vividly remember the morning when I started my first job'. Removing the negation while maintaining virtually the same meaning empowers intelligent systems to understand the positive meaning hidden in sentences containing negation.
